## Request

[[find in source code]](..\..\..\..\..\env\Lib\site-packages\flask\wrappers.py#L30)

```python
class Request(RequestBase, JSONMixin):
```

The request object used by default in Flask.  Remembers the
matched endpoint and view arguments.

It is what ends up as class `flask.request`.  If you want to replace
the request object used you can subclass this and set
attribute `~flask.Flask.request_class` to your subclass.

The request object is a class `werkzeug.wrappers.Request` subclass and
provides all of the attributes Werkzeug defines plus a few Flask
specific ones.

#### Attributes

- `url_rule` - : The internal URL rule that matched the request.  This can be
  : useful to inspect which methods are allowed for the URL from
  : a before/after handler (``request.url_rule.methods``) etc.
  : Though if the request's method was invalid for the URL rule,
  : the valid list is available in ``routing_exception.valid_methods``
  : instead (an attribute of the Werkzeug exception
  : :exc:`~werkzeug.exceptions.MethodNotAllowed`)
  : because the request was never internally bound.
  :
  : .. versionadded:: 0.6: `None`
- `view_args` - : A dict of view arguments that matched the request.  If an exception
  : happened when matching, this will be ``None``.: `None`
- `routing_exception` - : If matching the URL failed, this is the exception that will be
  : raised / was raised as part of the request handling.  This is
  : usually a :exc:`~werkzeug.exceptions.NotFound` exception or
  : something similar.: `None`

#### See also

- [JSONMixin](#jsonmixin)

### Request().blueprint

[[find in source code]](..\..\..\..\..\env\Lib\site-packages\flask\wrappers.py#L81)


The name of the current blueprint

### Request().endpoint

[[find in source code]](..\..\..\..\..\env\Lib\site-packages\flask\wrappers.py#L71)

```python
@property
def endpoint():
```

The endpoint that matched the request.  This in combination with
:attr:[view_args](#request) can be used to reconstruct the same or a
modified URL.  If an exception happened when matching, this will
be ``None``.

### Request().max_content_length

[[find in source code]](..\..\..\..\..\env\Lib\site-packages\flask\wrappers.py#L65)

```python
@property
def max_content_length():
```

Read-only view of the ``MAX_CONTENT_LENGTH`` config key.

## Response

[[find in source code]](..\..\..\..\..\env\Lib\site-packages\flask\wrappers.py#L103)

```python
class Response(ResponseBase, JSONMixin):
```

The response object that is used by default in Flask.  Works like the
response object from Werkzeug but is set to have an HTML mimetype by
default.  Quite often you don't have to create this object yourself because
:meth:`~flask.Flask.make_response` will take care of that for you.

If you want to replace the response object used you can subclass this and
set attribute `~flask.Flask.response_class` to your subclass.

#### Notes

Changed in version 1.0
    JSON support is added to the response, like the request. This is useful
    when testing to get the test client response data as JSON.

Changed in version 1.0

Added attribute `max_cookie_size`.

#### See also

- [JSONMixin](#jsonmixin)

### Response().max_cookie_size

[[find in source code]](..\..\..\..\..\env\Lib\site-packages\flask\wrappers.py#L126)

```python
@property
def max_cookie_size():
```

Read-only view of the `MAX_COOKIE_SIZE` config key.

See attribute `~werkzeug.wrappers.BaseResponse.max_cookie_size` in
Werkzeug's docs.
